The structure of hydrate is of great importance for understanding the formation mechanism of hydrate, the physical properties of hydrate, and the storage and release of hydrate in the deep ocean. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and low temperature. The structure of neon hydrate is of great importance for understanding the formation mechanism of hydrate, the physical properties of hydrate, and the storage and release of hydrate in the deep ocean.

The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. In this paper, we provide a categorical characterization of Hilbert space and the linear operators on it. This resolves a question raised in the context of these reconstruction programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. They are also the most reduced group of animals, with the smallest genomes and the fewest number of genes. Here, we report the first genomic and transcriptomic analyses of two species of myxozoans, which are the sister group to all other myxozoans. We show that myxozoans are cnidarians, and that the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content is a general feature of the group. Our results provide insights into the evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasite. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic is a serious global health problem. The virus responsible for this disease, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the STAT1 and STAT2 proteins. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is essential for nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and could be used to design new strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. In the male reproductive system, sperm cells are quiescent due to the inhibition of proton channels by zinc, but become active once introduced into the female reproductive tract, where zinc is absent. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of proton channels. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These results provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the future variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Less)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level food-plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for more comprehensive, species-level diet analyses in future studies of LMH ecology and conservation.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off employees and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a growing problem in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by food webs and ballasting processes. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important unsolved problems in astronomy. We determined the age of the solar system by measuring the exposure age of presolar silicon carbide grains. The grains were extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite, which was formed in the aftermath of a supernova explosion. We found that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago, which is the time when an episode of enhanced star formation occurred.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of resources available to the mother is a key factor in the success of all species that practice allonursing. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a female cares for her offspring by providing food and/or care from another female, is associated with increased reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the amount of resources available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters produced. This result suggests that the limiting factor in the number of litters produced by placental mammals is the mother’s metabolic power. This result has implications for the evolution of all forms of allonursing and the evolution of domestication. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of the toxic forms of α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA. (Read more)

The endothelium is the single layer of cells that lines all blood vessels. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation, and regulating blood pressure. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, and to be highly efficient in the transmission of information. Here, we show that the network is small-world in nature, and that the cells are connected by shortcuts to reduce the path length between them. This design provides the endothelium with the ability to rapidly and efficiently integrate information from the entire vascular bed. This is important for the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic, and for research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to a wide range of users, and encourage the community to contribute to and use the API.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and for the collapse of the selectivity filter on activation. We also provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a molecular understanding of the allosteric coupling in potassium channels and opens the way to the development of new drugs.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. The composition of the microbiome is important for health and disease, and the host–microbiome interactions are complex and poorly understood. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi and are likely to be important for their survival in the gut. These findings support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait associated with a low probability to become dominant, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low energy state of high-anxious animals is responsible for their low social competitiveness and that this is reversed by nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 that enhances brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These findings have implications for understanding the role of anxiety in social behavior and for the development of new treatments for social anxiety disorder. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis method to design structures with multiple material phases, which are digitally synthesized to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically realized. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a complex of proteins that is essential for the transport of oxygen in the blood. The hemoglobin system is regulated by a number of factors, including the hemoglobin gene regulatory network, the oxygen sensor, and the oxygen sensor-mediated regulation of hemoglobin expression. Here we show that a factor that is involved in the regulation of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) affects the hemoglobin system. This finding suggests that the IGF2BP1 factor may be involved in the regulation of the hemoglobin system.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the number of cancer patients is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. Cancer is a heterogeneous disease, and the same patient can have different types of cancer at different times. The most common form of cancer is caused by mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, which is also the most common target for cancer therapy. In this study, we found that the same patient with cancer can have different resistance mechanisms to cancer therapy, and that the resistance mechanisms are highly dependent on the genetic background of the patient. We also found that cancer therapy can be combined with ferroptosis induction to achieve near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. This study provides a new strategy for cancer therapy. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of antihypertensive drugs is increasing. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). We show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. The NWFP has been criticized for not going far enough, but our findings suggest that the policy was not ambitious enough. We show that the NWFP’s main achievement was to halt the clearcutting of old-growth forests. However, this has not been enough to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird species. We conclude that the NWFP needs to be strengthened to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We also show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for the problem of semantic segmentation of satellite images. The code for the proposed architecture is available at this https URL .

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT highstands are observed during times of high eccentricity. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. However, the impact of this technology on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, reduces the amount of sleep, and delays the circadian clock, all of which have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments and magnetic grains from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases has been extensively studied, but the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in the adult is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in the adult mouse results in the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, which are not observed in congenital deficiency. These diseases are associated with the expansion of Treg cells, which is not observed in congenital deficiency.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, and to understand the role of plant feeding in their diversification. We show that beetles diversified in the Mesozoic, and that the evolution of plant-feeding beetles was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19 by accelerating the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics. This work may also help to reduce the burden of other viruses in the future.

We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We find that, in the absence of other factors, larger populations do not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that the size of the population is not the only factor that determines the extent to which cumulative cultural evolution occurs.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 increases risk by ∼12-fold. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere of iron that is about 1200 km in diameter and 12 km in radius. It is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the planet. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the physics and chemistry of the deep interior of the Earth. The inner core is also a key part of the geodynamo, the dynamo that generates the Earth's magnetic field. The inner core is also a challenge for understanding the evolution of the Earth. The inner core is likely to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is the only species-specific cognitive ability that is universal across cultures and languages. It is also the most complex cognitive skill that the human brain has evolved to perform. In this work, we use a powerful machine learning approach to study the human brain’s neural representation of language. We find that deep learning models, which are trained on natural language without any linguistic supervision, are able to predict the neural responses to sentences with high accuracy. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are shaped by the predictive processing of natural language. These results provide computational evidence for the universality and fundamental importance of language processing in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be made stable, i.e., whether it can be made to converge to a unique solution. We show that this is not the case for a number of well-conditioned problems in scientific computing. We also introduce a new class of neural networks that we prove are stable and numerically verify to be fast and accurate. This work is a step toward the development of a theory of stability for DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of exponential growth. The exponential growth curve is a mathematical model that is widely used to describe the spread of infectious diseases. It is also a model that is notoriously difficult for people to understand. This is the main reason why the COVID-19 pandemic is so difficult to control. In this article, we discuss a classic psychological experiment that was published 45 years ago. The experiment is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed and that it is therefore not possible to draw any conclusions from it.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and is still a major cause of disability in the developing world. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of a patient from Mexico, who was diagnosed as having a reactional form of leprosy, and show that this form is caused by a new species of mycobacterium, M. lepromatosis. This study provides a unique opportunity to compare the genomes of two leprosy bacilli, which are ancient relatives, and to understand the evolutionary forces that have shaped them. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two key concepts standing at the foundations of quantum and statistical mechanics. They are also the two quantities that are most difficult to compute exactly in quantum many-body systems. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most difficult regime for exact computations. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. This result is a major step forward in the understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is being developed by our group. The vaccine is based on a recoded segment of the viral spike protein, which is the viral protein that engages with the host immune system. The recoded spike protein is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is protective in a relevant hamster model and is being tested in a phase I/II clinical trial. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been a human ectoparasite vector. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe. It also has implications for the spread of plague in the Americas, where human ectoparasites were also present.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most important topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain size is not always a good proxy for the evolution of brain function. This study shows that the evolution of the brain is better understood by analyzing the evolution of the number of neurons in the brain.

The mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the utility of current TRAP1 inhibitors is limited by their ability to distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the other major target of these drugs. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are also the main targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We show that the mechanical state of the filament network can strongly influence the ADF/cofilin action. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results have implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin action in cells and for the design of new drugs.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island has been settled by multiple waves of migration, with a recent contribution of European and Middle Eastern origin. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island shows that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the contribution of Africa and Asia was not equal. These results suggest that the island was settled by multiple waves of migration, and that the contribution of Africa and Asia was not equal. This is important for understanding the history of Madagascar, and for the study of the human population dynamics in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Emotional contagion is the process by which people experience the same emotions as others. It is well established in laboratory experiments, but the extent to which it occurs in the real world is unclear. In this work, we show that people do experience the same emotions as others in the real world, and that this occurs even when people are not interacting in person. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into protein sequences. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome encounters. In addition to the mRNA, the ribosome encounters the mRNA’s complementary strand, the tRNA anticodons, and the amino acids that are being added to the protein. In this work, we show that the ribosome can also encounter modifications of the mRNA. We find that the presence of a modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis and the rate of translation of a specific codon. These findings suggest that the presence of mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on the translation of the mRNA. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in the fossil record, but the underlying mechanisms are unclear. We use a model of energy intake and energy expenditure to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the innate immune response of infected cells. Rhinovirus infection of mouse airway cells leads to a less efficient antiviral defense response at cool temperature, which is associated with higher levels of viral replication.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface adhesin type IV pili to sense the environment and regulate its virulence. This is achieved by a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of the pili is sensed by a chemosensory system, and the resulting signal is amplified by a positive feedback loop. This mechanism is essential for the pathogen to survive and cause disease in the host.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is very low, and that the risk they pose to aquatic biodiversity is high. This study provides a basis for further research and for the development of effective strategies for the reduction of pesticide use in agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus has the potential to persist in deer populations. These findings have important implications for the future of the pandemic and the need for a more integrated approach to study the ecology and evolution of the virus. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global health crisis. The disease is thought to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein in the brain, but the earliest pathological events are poorly understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the most toxic amyloid species within the brain, and that it is the Aβ-burdened neuron that initiates the inflammatory response. This neuron-specific inflammatory reaction may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may therefore represent a therapeutic target for the treatment of AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of this species. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest known site where chickens were exploited for economic purposes. We show that the frequency of chicken bones in the Southern Levant increased sharply during the Hellenistic period, and that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the finds in the Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study contributes to the debate on the origin of the chicken and its spread in the world. (Less)

We have studied the folding of the large maltose binding protein (MBP) at atomic resolution. We have found that the folding of MBP is a two-step process. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are known to function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap of Np4-capped RNAs in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4 accumulation. We also show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap of triphosphorylated RNAs, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping those transcripts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that citrulline, an amino acid that is derived from arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation in a mouse model of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the deep subsurface. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are a key step toward a better understanding of the structure and dynamics of the Earth system.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can be driven out of equilibrium and then evolve in a self-sustaining manner. SOC is characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of relaxation times, and is observed in a variety of systems, including sandpiles, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized without phonon instability, and that its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new strategies for the control of plant fungal diseases. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are expressed in the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. We have solved the NMR structure of one of the peptides, which is highly dynamic and largely disordered. We have also shown that this peptide is highly active against plant fungal pathogens. This work provides a proof of concept for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the contributions of males and females are intertwined. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female contributions to the sperm proteome are detectable immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by conformational changes. We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the observed effects of mutations in VWF.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and has only recently begun to be explored. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human virome, and is the first to use a large number of publicly available metagenomic datasets to identify associations between viruses and diseases. The results of this study are expected to have a significant impact on the study of the human virome, and will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system, but is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously profile aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution, and can be used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This instrument is expected to be a significant contribution to the climate science.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature inferred from isotopic data is in some cases in conflict with the temperature inferred from protein reconstruction. We here present a method for determining the temperature history of the Earth based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. This method is shown to be consistent with the temperature history inferred from isotopic data.

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of ion flow in the cell. They are also the targets of drugs and toxins. The K+ channel, BK, is a ubiquitous channel that is involved in a wide range of physiological processes. It is also a target of many drugs. We found that the BK channel has two gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s inactivation is state-dependent and that its rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of its inactivation. This finding may help to understand the BK channel’s pharmacology and physiology. (Show more)

Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the role of the RBC in the process has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment and control of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be completely opened, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in humans. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These findings may help to develop strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. This article is protected by copyright. All

We report the first intracranial evidence for the merge operation, a fundamental operation in the construction of syntactic structures. We show that the brain detects the merge of words into phrases and that this operation is applied equally to words in a sentence and to words in a list of words. We also show that the brain uses this operation to build a hierarchy of phrases, which is consistent with a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide neurophysiological support for the claim that the brain is a parser of language. This is an important step forward in our understanding of the brain’s processing of language.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a dual-functional protein that can be either a scaffold or a phosphatase. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique opportunity to study the role of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is a key nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is often a limiting factor. In agriculture, the vast majority of nitrogen is fixed by bacteria and delivered to the plant as nitrogen gas. However, this process is inefficient, and the nitrogenase, the enzyme responsible for this reaction, is highly sensitive to environmental factors, such as oxygen and temperature. We have developed a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant, and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to deliver nitrogen in a sustainable manner, with the potential to improve crop productivity and food security. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global problems. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development has been rapid, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. We report an engineered SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) that is well-suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. This engineered RBD is more manufacturable, has higher affinity to the ACE2 receptor, and induces a stronger antibody response than the Wuhan-Hu-1 RBD used in current vaccines. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that this engineered RBD can be used in a vaccine to provide global access to COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. We also show that the loss of DrLtk and DrALK causes distinct patterns of iridophore loss in zebrafish larvae and that the loss of DrALK causes embryonic lethality. These results provide in vivo evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKALS in neural crest development. Our findings are important for understanding the role of ALK/ALKALS in human cancer and for the development of zebrafish models for human diseases. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of bacterial evolution. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time period for understanding the evolution of plague. We find that plague underwent a series of evolutionary steps during this period, and that the genetic diversity of plague was low during this time. We also find that plague was not restricted to a single geographic region, but instead spread across Eurasia. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague, and its early evolution and dispersal. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and the world.

The agricultural management of grasslands and croplands is a key determinant of the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to croplands has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that the management of croplands and grasslands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil. We also show that the management of grasslands can be used to sequester carbon in the soil, and that this management can be used to sequester carbon in the soil on a global scale.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to cause disease outbreaks in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a valuable resource for the global scientific community and the public. We hope that it will be used to inform the development of effective strategies for the prevention and control of future viral threats.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work suggests that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular framework for the study of nectar chemistry. (Show more)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from the late 5th/early 6th century AD, who exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing effective countermeasures against future zoonotic outbreaks. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in this resource-scarce setting. We also identified the risk factors associated with undifferentiated febrile illness. Our findings suggest that the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings can provide a rapid and unbiased approach to identify a broad range of pathogens, which can be used to inform public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of DNA strands in the 3′ to 5′ direction. This process is known as DNA replication and is essential for the proper functioning of all living organisms. The process is carried out by a complex of proteins and enzymes, known as the replisome, which is responsible for the synthesis of the new strand. This study provides a detailed analysis of the structure and function of the replisome in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which is able to synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. The polymerase can also replicate RNA, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can now be used to reconstruct the replication of genetic information and the conversion of RNA into functional molecules in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of data to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

COVID-19 is a new disease, and the pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. We used tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, to treat the patients, and the results were encouraging.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause severe damage to cells. The ability of fungi to bind copper and sequester it intracellularly is well established, but the role of this process in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal interactions with other microbes is less well understood. We report here the identification of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of this copper-binding fungal natural product in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this process in the regulation of fungal interactions with competing microbes. This work provides a new perspective on the role of fungal natural products in the control of fungal interactions with other microbes. (Read more)

Silica is a major component of the Martian surface, and its origin and evolution are important to understanding the planet. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. We report the detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, and its cogenetic detrital feldspar and cristobalite, which are possibly derived from silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The presence of primary amorphous silica, post-lithification fracture/vein fill, and the absence of carbonates suggest that the Martian surface has been exposed to multiple aqueous episodes. These results provide insights into the evolution of the Martian surface and its climate. (Abridged)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is determined by the evolutionary history of the species involved, and that the resistance strategies of species are adapted to the local frost risk. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management and forestry practices to the changing frost risk, and to develop insurance policies that can help farmers and foresters cope with the economic impact of frost damage.

Th17 cells are a heterogeneous subset of CD4+ T cells that are important in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapies. This method will enable the study of ALS in the living patient, and the rapid generation of disease models for drug screening.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s colonization. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of arthropod vectors and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The earliest members of the clade Pygostylia are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without a thorough understanding of the underlying processes. In this paper, we show that one of the most important processes is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing temperature. This increase in water vapor is a feedback that amplifies the climate response.

Vertebrates have evolved a wide variety of colors, from red to blue, and even to ultraviolet. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates is not a recent phenomenon, but has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in this group. Breast cancer cells are characterized by the ability to form cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of a pluripotency factor, NANOG, in breast cancer cells, and that this is mediated by hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-dependent expression of the m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5). ALKBH5 expression is increased in breast cancer cells in response to hypoxia, and this correlates with the development of cancer stem cell properties. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of the parchment in any manuscript. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding the causes of the event and its impact on the evolution of life on Earth. We report the age of the extinction at Meishan, China, and show that the onset of the extinction coincides with a major reorganization of the carbon cycle.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in various biological processes, including cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of RORα in intestinal homeostasis and inflammation, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the spike protein in complex with the receptor, ACE2, and the cellular membrane. We find that the spike protein is in a more open conformation in the presence of the D614G mutation. This may facilitate the binding of the virus to the cellular receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.
