The chemical properties of atoms are of great importance in chemistry, biology, and materials science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of great interest for the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure, and for the design of new materials.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon. We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emission scenarios, and it can offset up to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon. This will be critical for the development of effective climate mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is specifically required for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid’s host epithelium is acidified by the symbionts. This acidification is required for the symbionts to produce bioluminescence, suggesting that the glycan provision is a mechanism for regulating the activity of the symbionts. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiont activity and the role of glycans in animal–microbe interactions. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We show that our method can be used to identify gender biases in topics and to compare the gendered nature of topics to the gendered nature of the data. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and it can be extended to other types of data. We believe that it will be useful to many researchers and practitioners.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, and in particular the temperature and precipitation conditions in the vicinity of the Silk Road, were important drivers of the introduction of plague into Europe. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic and its impact on human history. (Less)

We report on the discovery of a sea star wasting disease on the Pacific Coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with a dramatic loss of species diversity. We also show that the disease is highly contagious and that it can be transmitted by the movement of sick animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The disease is characterized by the presence of a small number of cells that are able to self-renew and differentiate into all blood cell lineages. We have previously shown that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on these cells and that antibodies targeting IL1RAP are able to kill these cells in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that these antibodies are able to kill AML cells in a manner dependent on antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and IL-1 signaling. We also show that the antibodies are able to kill AML cells in a manner that is dependent on natural killer cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the island is a mosaic of different ancestries. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event, but rather a series of events, each one with its own demographic and genetic signature. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it will be useful for future studies of the human history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the burden of COVID-19 by accelerating the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics. This work may also help to reduce the burden of other viruses in the future.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing information on crop status that is critical for agricultural decision-making. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status in the US, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey exhibits long-term stability and is valid across different crops, and that it can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of crop expert surveys to provide a more complete picture of agricultural production, and to improve our understanding of the state of the world’s agricultural systems.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain’s ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of this process. We show that the brain can maintain information in the form of changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, and the time constant of the changes in excitability determines the memory span. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major carbon flux in the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, and the results have been inconsistent. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and it demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This work highlights the need for more studies to be conducted in a variety of ecosystems. We also highlight the need for more studies to be conducted in a variety of ecosystems.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of the plant kingdom. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is accompanied by a reduction in the number of genes and the complexity of the encoded proteins. We show that the transition to parasitism is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise deceleration of the evolutionary rates of the genes. Our findings provide a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of the plant kingdom. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our findings are important for water resource managers and policy makers in SSA and elsewhere. They highlight the need for urgent action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is significant because it provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the creation of the first nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy into chemical energy. The conversion of solar energy into chemical energy is achieved by the capture of light by pigments, the conversion of light energy into chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The first step in the conversion of light into chemical energy is the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the formation of which has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, one of which is O2 sensitive, the other O2 dependent. We show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a subunit of the O2-sensitive enzyme, and that the O2-dependent enzyme is required for oxygenic photosynthesis. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the O2-dependent cyclase. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is associated with the development of disability. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, and one of the most important signaling pathways is the mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K)/extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK)/stress-activated protein kinase (SAPK) pathway. In this study, we found that apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a key regulator of neuroinflammation in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a widely used animal model of MS. We also found that ASK1 is a key regulator of glial cell interactions in EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the pathophysiology of EAE and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for MS. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most severe droughts in the state’s history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. This finding is important because it suggests that the probability of drought will continue to increase in the future, even if global warming is limited to 2 °C or 3 °C.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and their functions, which will facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies for autism. (Show more)

This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in this regard. The results suggest that, on average, the public is more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. This is a significant finding, given that the news media are arguably the most important source of information for the general public. The results also suggest that there is reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that result in a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. We also identify mutations in the ORAI1 pore-forming protein that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of miosis and tubular myopathy, but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that this process is non–cell-autonomous. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the mechanisms by which viruses spill over from bats to other animals and humans are largely unknown. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein is a potent immunosuppressant. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunosuppressant protein. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of viral spillover from bats to other animals and humans. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is critical for the production of the one-carbon unit. We have shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We have also shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of lymphoma cells, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic target and a metabolic deficiency that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work has implications for the treatment of cancer, lymphoma, and other diseases that are dependent upon the one-carbon unit. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects motor neurons and is caused by a variety of genetic mutations. These mutations lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies, which are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for a wide range of applications in quantum information processing, quantum simulation, and quantum metrology. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for a wide range of applications in quantum information processing, quantum simulation, and quantum metrology.

The Cretaceous is often considered to be the age of dinosaurs, but it is also a time of great biodiversity and ecological change. The Cretaceous is also the age of the first flowering plants, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous of the Pyrenees. We show that Montsechia is a member of the Ceratophyllum clade, which is sister to eudicots. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is often studied by comparing the genetic sequences of viruses from different times and places. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvoviruses, which were isolated from human remains from as early as ∼12.6 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. These changes are the result of a complex interplay of natural and human factors. The dominant natural factor is the thermal expansion of the oceans, which is caused by the increase in sea surface temperature resulting from the build-up of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. The human factors include the increase in the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere, which is caused by human activities, and the increase in the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere is caused by the increase in sea surface temperature.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this pattern continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key intermediate in the mechanism of a pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzyme. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions, and it provides a model for the application of this approach to other enzymes and reaction mechanisms.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly identified coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of coronavirus infections. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is specifically required for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, and that its catabolism is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ, which is essential for the bacterium to produce light. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbioses. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention on teachers’ mindsets about discipline. The intervention was designed to be scalable and to be implemented by teachers themselves. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The intervention halved the rate of student suspensions in the participating schools. It also bolstered the respect that students had for their teachers.

Alkylation of DNA is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a wide range of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia, and the virus is a potential threat to global health. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first S proteolysis steps are important for MERS-CoV infection into human lung cells, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food system also has the potential to contribute to population health, but this potential is currently unrealized. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This has the potential to contribute to both environmental and population health goals.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, and KRAS, in a single cell line. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a framework for understanding the cell surface proteome in cancer. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

SARS-CoV-2 is the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. The virus has a large number of accessory proteins that are not present in other coronaviruses. One of these proteins, ORF8, has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using transfected cells, we show that transfected CRFR1 contributes to edema via transfected AQP4. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal of selective inference is to assess the strength of associations in the data, while taking into account that we have “cherry-picked” the data. This is a challenge that is becoming more important as the size of the data increases and the tools for “cherry picking” become more sophisticated.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. In addition, we show that ETV2 is a promising therapeutic approach for the treatment of ischemic disorders. These findings provide a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for the “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a number of additional RTKs with similar properties. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor, in the eye and the body. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the role of RTKs in vertebrate development. (Show more)

Insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to infect a wide range of species, including humans, and cause severe diseases. The influenza A genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which favors their co-packaging into the same viral particle. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that is initiated by the activation of proatherogenic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we identified a critical role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of vascular endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire and associated hazards should focus on reducing the number of human-started wildfires.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and regions, and to study the physical consequences of social, economic, and environmental change.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent surge in cases has led to a global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques, and we assess the effect of an antiviral treatment. Our results can help to guide the development of effective treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work is a major step forward in our ability to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that protects the organism from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a dynamic tissue that can be perturbed by the presence of tumors and the microbiome. We demonstrate that the tumorigenesis process leads to the activation of a JNK-dependent feedback loop that triggers a regenerative response in the epithelium, leading to a dysbiosis of the microbiome and a loss of the intestinal barrier. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and inflammatory bowel diseases. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and is associated with a high rate of treatment failure. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, and that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is associated with the repression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a unique and well-dated volcanic eruption. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is instead linked to a series of massive volcanic eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong El Niño-like climate event. This is a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can have a large impact on climate, and it provides a new perspective on the causes of the last glacial period. This work has implications for our understanding of the causes of the last glacial period and the potential for future climate change. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are a globally important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. Our analysis highlights the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need to protect these ecosystems from overfishing and other threats. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are a promising solution for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining regenerative neurons are unable to repair injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult C. elegans nervous system that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathways known to mediate regeneration in other species. This discovery opens the door to a new approach for discovering genes that control the ability of neurons to regenerate in the adult mammalian CNS.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense activity. The distribution of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The present study provides a method for the identification of resting state networks in the human brain, based on the analysis of metabolic signals. This method was used to identify a dominant resting state network in healthy subjects, which was subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. The dominant network was also associated with reduced cerebral blood flow in healthy subjects and with increased blood flow in PD patients. The subordinate networks were associated with increased blood flow in healthy subjects and in PD patients during task performance. These results provide a method for the identification of resting state networks in the human brain, and for the study of their functional significance.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is required for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD+ mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD+ is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery is important for understanding the function of NAD+ in cells and the evolution of the 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes. (Read more)

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of the disease. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of their flavor is of great importance to consumers. The production of the diverse array of volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is not well understood. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the production of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. (Read more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are dependent on the thermal tolerance traits of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of climate change and biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons are organized into distinct cell types that are thought to represent different aspects of the environment. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to represent the local environment, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, which are thought to represent the global environment. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types in the brain. They will help to advance our understanding of the neural basis of navigation. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the role of FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) in flowering regulation is more complex than previously thought. We show that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine-containing nigro–striato–nigral loop is a critical system for the control of movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing dendrites of nigral neurons form bouquet-like arborizations that are innervated by striatonigral fibers originating in the striatum. These striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given the role of striosomes in mood and motivation, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to gauge the quality of their connections with others, and by listeners to gauge the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. In this study, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the SAN and is required for the function of the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the function of the SAN by modulating the activity of the Ca2+ release machinery and the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These findings reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in the SAN and provide a molecular mechanism for how STIM1 may contribute to the regulation of heart rate. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivores have been well documented. However, the role of silicon in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been fully understood. Here, we show that silicon pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by jasmonic acid (JA), a key signaling molecule in plant defense. Our results suggest that silicon and JA may interact to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system, which is constantly responding to the environment. In this study, we show that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. We also show that the activity of this enzyme is regulated by tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor essential for nitric oxide synthesis. Our results demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of ether lipids in the biology of macrophages and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with ether lipid dysregulation. (Show more)

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms. Here we propose a new approach to language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to change their properties in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory for the contents of working memory. We demonstrate that this approach can account for a number of experimental observations and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on the ability of neurons to change their properties in response to experience. It is a step toward a more complete understanding of the neural basis of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they have evolved a number of defense mechanisms to protect themselves from pathogens and other environmental stresses. One of the most important defense mechanisms is the production of siRNAs, which are then used to silence the expression of the pathogen or stressor. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver siRNAs to plants, which can then be used to silence the expression of a target gene. We also show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and silencing of the target gene. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology.

Nutrient inputs to lakes and reservoirs are often dominated by small tributaries, but these systems are often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient pollution. We show that the majority of the nutrients delivered to Lake Michigan by its tributaries are from a small number of large watersheds. However, these large watersheds are not the only drivers of coastal nutrient inputs. Small watersheds are also important, and their nutrient inputs are more biologically available to fuel algal blooms. Our findings highlight the need to address nutrient inputs from all watersheds, large and small, to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution in lakes and reservoirs.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. We show that the dynamics of the network are dominated by a small number of chemical species that are able to absorb the environmental work and drive the system to a stable, far-from-equilibrium state.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We also show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, and that this can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs, and may help to explain the diversity of EEG abnormalities observed in patients.

The history of Earth’s climate is characterized by abrupt warming events, which are often associated with changes in the carbon cycle. However, the history of carbon perturbation events throughout Earth’s history is not well understood. Here, we present a study of an abrupt carbon perturbation and global warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state. We show that the event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the event was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to near 20% of areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Our study provides insights into the history of carbon perturbation events and the Earth system response to abrupt warming. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and the use of sustainability certification is one of the most important tools for reducing this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. We show that certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation, but that most certified areas still contain substantial amounts of forest. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, but that it is an important tool for reducing the impact of palm oil on tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the number of sexes in a species is often a reflection of the history of the species. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a cichlid fish. We find that the number of sexes in a species is not fixed, but can be modular, and that the number of sexes can be increased through the acquisition of new sex determination alleles. These results provide a framework for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photodegrading species. We sought to understand how the levels of iron, a key redox active metal, impacts the retina. We found that iron levels impact the retina in a manner that is dependent on the levels of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, which are photodegrading species. These findings have implications for the retina in health and disease.

Predator specialization is a key evolutionary process in the diversification of animal communities. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a key step in the diversification of predatory morphology. Our results show that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of the tentacles and their prey-capture structures. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. (Less)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is a key metabolic intermediate. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase, which is critical for the production of the one-carbon unit. We have shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We have also shown that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of lymphoma cells, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of lymphoma cells. These results suggest that the one-carbon unit is a promising metabolic target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated in areas where people have limited access to natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and, in turn, their health and nutrition.

Mechanization has greatly contributed to the success of modern agriculture, with vastly expanded food production capabilities achieved by the higher capacity of farm machinery. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a more holistic approach
